title: Sunfire cape is completely overshadowed by Deadman's plate now.
body:
One could argue its cheaper but deadman's gives a lot of beneficial stats to a tanky frontliner like move speed for initiation, higher armor and more HP than sunfire it also does damage itself while being pretty low.

Where sunfire is ment to be damaging tank item it seems completely outclassed.
I honestly think sunfire should be changed to have it scale on your own hp in damage.

Something like 10+1.5% max HP

> [{quoted}](name=RiotRepertoir,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=ji7ME6sY,comment-id=002b,timestamp=2015-09-22T19:59:02.168+0000)

Hey man--if you want to know what I think, just ask!

Personally, I think the breakdown here is mostly that Dead Man's Plate gives greater rewards because it requires actions to "unlock" them (you have to move around without getting hit by CC, and it's basically done doing its thing once you've initiated--which is great, because it has defined strengths and weaknesses as a niche item for champs that want more initiation power), whereas Sunfire is basically at this constant, steady burn so it can't really do anything at DMP levels of cool since it's "always at 100%" more or less.

The Cinderhulk upgrade in one of its earlier iterations was pretty interesting, in that it was essentially Sunfire cape with more gameplay to it--this is the item that would allow a tank to be a threat if left alive, and largely benefited champions that wanted to commit to longer fights, a back-loaded power compared to DMP's front-loaded power. Since that in-combat scaling is no longer a part of Cinderhulk, I think reincorporating it into Sunfire's passive effect will not only make the two more distinct from each other, it could also allow it to be more situationally powerful and thus a match for DMP's situational power. (This could also be a neat tandem "AoE magic burn threat" with the new Abyssal Scepter if it ever makes it to live, much in the same way that Rylai's and Liandry's play so well together--allowing tankier champions to sacrifice some durability for raw aggro generation)

Or you can just buff the numbers a bit to make it more gold-efficient, I guess that works too.

It would be cool if Sunfire had more going on to it rather than _just_ flat burn damage as an aura. Wouldn't it be neat if the power of the cape could be stored to release an explosion around the player after taking a set amount of damage? It would make sunfire a lot more interesting of a purchase for tanks and initiators that way, and provide some interesting build opportunities.

> [{quoted}](name=UltimaFatum,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=ji7ME6sY,comment-id=002b0000,timestamp=2015-09-22T20:28:35.355+0000)
>
> Wouldn't it be neat if the power of the cape could be stored to release an explosion around the player after taking a set amount of damage?

Maybe something like Odyn's Veil, but for physical damage instead of magic damage? It would make it more interesting, although they would probably have to reduce the burn damage then (or remove it altogether).

I feel like right now Sunfire Cape's burn simply isn't strong enough to be efficient during a teamfight, and even less so during a skirmish. Some of Sunfire's damage should be frontloaded so that there's an immediate benefit to buying it over Dead Man's plate, which can detonate a full charge of its passive upon AA.

Over the last two or three patches I've seen so many nerfs to 6 item scaling tank builds and to tank survivability that it feels like a whole new game, and not in a good way. Biggest gripe: Thornmail got gutted. Utterly gutted. Thornmail, randuin, and frozen were the three items that you can buy if you just want to not-die to specifically the adc. Today though, all three have been hit medium hard. I did the math, and the new randuins is worse against ADCs before ten crits. It's almost impossible to tank ten crits before running out of health. Frozen heart getting a cost increase I'm okay with. The power is high, the price can be high. Thornmail is horrible. Doing the math, you need an impossible amount of armor to get halfway to the old reflected damage against an ad carry. With that out of my arsenal, life is really hard.

I want to see pure-defensive tank items come back, Spirit visage is a good one, but none of the armor items give you a six item scaling chance in the lategame.
Comparing the game a few patches ago to the game now is a totally valid and useful way to think about balance. It's not the whole story, but it's specifically what RiotRep asked for in this thread.
Armor items "sucked" before and reusing the same argument is unneeded. Nothing really changed from before.

Here are the specific arguments that I was making by pointing out the change in last month's patch.

Randuins: -100 hp - 10 armor. -600 effective health at 5000 hp vs physical. +10% reduction on crits. Stack with Reinforced armor to grant 400-40=360-36=324 damage received =76 reduced damage assuming a 400 damage crit auto. After ~8-9 crit auto attacks from an ADC, new randuins is better. ~3000 damage received in both cases, ignoring non-crits. Factoring in non-crits feels like it makes new Randuin's quite a bit worse.

Thornmail: If I'm reading right, you can get ~200 bonus armor lategame, and deal 100 extra reflection damage. Carries autoing you would get reflected for a ton more than this when they crit before the changes, but now it's more normalized, where a reflect deals a much more consistent value, regardless of the attacker's damage. Thornmail reflects less to lategame ADCs, but reflects much more to low damage incoming autos, making it better at small scraps, and significant against on-hit enemies (teemo, fizz, devour bruisers) and mages/supports who weave autos between casts. I'm concerned about it being harder to tank lategame ADCs with these combined changes of thorn/randuin

Dead Man's Plate: I'm concerned about the addition of mobility-enhancing tank items to the meta. If Juggernauts like Garen get too strong this patch, the stated solution is to remove some of his champion specific mobility. This concerns me because it can force him to find his mobility in items like this and glory, instead of having the freedom to build specifically tank resistances. These items are restrictive replacements for Garen's tenacity, and movement-speed duration that have already been taken out, and the thought of further reducing his mobility if he seems 'strong' makes me shiver.

Frozen heart, nothing much needs to be said. It's a few hundred gold harder to buy.



If I'm reusing this argument from someone else, please let me know, but I think it's the kind of specific feedback about the recent patches that RiotRepertoir was asking for.

How do you think Sunfire vs Cinderhulk is going?

I think Cinderhulk fits because tanks need the jungle clear, so it makes sense.

In top lane, I see it useful when you need to push the lane out, it makes sense on Malphite and Shen, maybe a few other tanks. Garen might not build it anymore since his spin does more damage and deadmans is better on him. 

Could I see him building it still? yeah in some situations, but only after deadmans plate.

Do you think this is matching what it should be doing? Being extra push power in lane?

I see Sunfire Cape as a tank item, and DMP as a juggernaut/bruiser item.

I can't think of many tanks, or at least any I play (Malph Cho Braum Thresh, and Blitz Gnar to a lesser extent), that really benefit from DMP's passives. Most of them already have ways to get in and disrupt the back line, so they don't really need Dreadnought (though it wouldn't hurt them), and most of them also drop off in damage pretty hard once they've unleashed their combo, which makes Crushing Blow both redundant and useless. This type of champ makes more sense to build Sunfire Cape on.

Juggernauts are tanky damage dealers, NOT tanks. Their purpose isn't to disrupt one team and peel for the other so much as to shred one or two squishies while ignoring the rest of the enemy team. Sunfire Cape doesn't make sense on them, because it's offensive against the team when they only want to murder one or two members. Further, they usually lack great engagement skills, and if they do have them (like Jax or Darius), it's hard to stick to the person they want to kill—and this is more important for juggernauts than tanks because their point is to stick to someone, not lock them down. DMP makes much more sense on these champions.

In a League that focuses more on bruisers than tanks, DMP will overshadow SF Cape, but that's not a bad thing, and there are still many champs that would rather build Cape than DMP.

However I am but a humble Bronzie so feel free to poke holes in that. Peace!

In terms of tank mobility, it would also be nice to have something that builds out of Raptor Cloak that wasn't niche like {{item:3056}} {{item:3512}}. Also tanks have {{item:3800}} (or {{item:3069}} for supports), which are more team-oriented and just fit better.

Both items fill a similar role: HP + Armor + Damage that doesn't come from extra AD or AP.

Sunfire gives you sustained damage, DMP gives you burst. Burst is generally better in the current meta.

The problem is that DMP also gives you mobility, which a ton of tanky champions are hungry for. In the League of Mobility, the sustained damage from Sunfire is less impactful simply because without heavy lockdown, you're not going to be standing next to someone long enough for the damage to stack up to any significant numbers.

One solution is to get rid of the Sunfire active and replace it with something like the passive on {{item:3151}} where auto attacks could apply a DoT burn, and you get additional movement speed when moving toward a target that's burning for extra chasing power (may need to make it melee only to prevent ranged abuse, hello {{champion:81}}). That way DMP could help you get to a target, and Sunfire could help you stick to that target. Similar items, different uses. And they have synergy with each other.

The last time Sunfire dealt good damage it defined the entire top lane meta, along with Spirit Visage. I'm not sure that we want that.

I think the biggest thing wrong with Sunfire Cape is that its passive isn't entirely a benefit. If you buy it, you can't freeze the lane, you can't push a tower, you can't go past jungle creeps without taking damage (including dewarding the epic monster pits). The damage isn't strictly an upside, and that's what's wrong with the item.

Making the passive a toggle instead or making it only apply in combat would go a long way to improving the item without having to make it better without fixing its problems.
